instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
Hi.

i have a macbook pro here that had liquid damage on the EDC180 area. checked ic and was shorted. replaced it with one from mouser and now i have 3.3v again ( with <RESISTOR>R3964</RESISTOR> AND <RESISTOR>R3965</RESISTOR> REMOVED) with these resistors in place the voltage is low. pulsing around 200-300ma when connected to a meter via USB-C.

checking from those resistors to ground im getting 1.3 ohms. also when checking PPBUS-G3H im only getting around 7v. pretty sure i have a short somewhere but unable to locate it even with a thermal camera.

the 1.3 ohms is in regards to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>. Is this a correct resistance reading for this line? 

Please save me from pulling anymore hair out.

thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
I suppose you've meant <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>/35 instead.

1.3 ohm is low enough to use voltage injection method.
Start with 1V and slowly increase, if needed; no more than 4V.
Set first amp limit on lab PSU to max.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 95501, member: 682"]
I suppose you've meant <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>/35 instead.

1.3 ohm is low enough to use voltage injection method.
Start with 1V and slowly increase, if needed; no more than 4V.
Set first amp limit on lab PSU to max.
[/QUOTE]
Hi thanks for the reply.


yes you are correct regarding the resistors. 

i did this and could not locate the issue. however i have found a shorted <CHIP>U8250</CHIP> on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. Removed it and tested both incoming and outgoing on the board and short is now gone. However i do not have a spare <CHIP>U8250</CHIP> anywhere. The part number according to schematic is SLGAP1569V/SLG5AP1569 depending on what part you read, searching this brings up nothing on google apart from aliexpress etc. however i can find a  slg59m1558v which looks to be the exact same part.
are you able to clarify this?

thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
Compare schematics which use both chips.
If they have the same size and pin layout, should work.

threads.message:

unfortunately the schematic for the one apple use is non existent. however they do list specs on their schematic which does mary up with the ones from mouser.

threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 95514, member: 682"]

also do you think it would be possible just to link it out for testing purposes? afterall it is only a switch

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
You can try a bypass, just for test.
Power on sequence timings will be affected, we don't know how PCH and T2 (SMC) will react.

Don't quote an entire post visible few centimeters above.
Write in the reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
Please, maintain forum aesthetic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
ok no problem.

so short removed from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, however my 1.3 ohms on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> is still there. connecting my psu up to it again @3v 2amps shows a heat signature coming from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. However it is faint given that is under a shield.  Im a bit puzzled as when checking the RTC 3.3v line on the board view nothing goes directly to that area. 

thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message: a bit more digging shows that pin 3-4 on <CHIP>U8290</CHIP> where shorted. now i still have 1.3 ohms on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_TBT_X_ISNS_R</SIGNAL> but unsure if this is normal or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
Because your short is on <SIGNAL>3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL>; this rail goes to <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.
Remove <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and test the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message: ok i did this and short has gone. i have replaced <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> with one from mouser and now its worse, im now getting 5v and 10ma on charger with and without battery. getting nothing out of <SIGNAL>3V3_RTC</SIGNAL> where i was before. loosing the will to live with this thing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message: Get <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> from donor board and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message: unfortunately i dont have one. i ordered 2 from mouser. both the same. however i think the issue is my using a little to much heat and the board has warped slightly. So annoyed with myself

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message: Check if board turns on removing <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message: battery is dead. i guess i can charge it using my DCPS to test this theory

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
Try with charger first.
Old models, prior T2, work without <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message: pretty sure this is 2019 model. like i said with usb-c it doesnt charge or do anything. just sits at 5v 5-10ma. only way to charge the battery will be either via another macbook the same (dont have one)or charging it from my DCPS which im used to doing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> HELP.
threads.message:
I didn't expect to charge the battery.
If stays at 5V with charger alone, test if is recognized in DFU mode.
